text:
One of your first steps with
AWS will be to build your landing
zone.

A landing zone is a well-architected,
multi-account AWS environment
that is scalable and secure.

It’s a starting point from which
your organization can quickly

launch and deploy workloads
and applications.

Avoid the temptation to overcomplicate
this step.

For even the largest organizations,
setting up a landing zone should
be a relatively quick process.

Excessive planning during
this foundational stage only

adds additional cost, and will
increase the time it will take

for you to start realizing
the benefits of the cloud.

One such benefit is the ability
to use infrastructure
as code.

Infrastructure as code allows
your organization to apply

the same rigor of application
development to infrastructure.

Rather than relying on manually
performed steps, which is time

consuming and error-prone,
you can deploy your compute,

storage, network, and application
services using configuration
files.

One of the great things about
this approach is that it makes

your infrastructure
deployments self-documenting.

It’s like having blueprints
for your IT infrastructure.

Through the reuse of this code,
you can replicate your development,

test, and production environments
while ensuring consistency
between them.

Or you can use it to replicate
between Regions to easily

build and maintain consistent
disaster recovery systems.

You can also use version
control to track and roll back
changes when needed.

This also allows you to create
reusable components by building

a library of 
infrastructure-as-code building blocks

that your organization can refine
and reuse over time.

And helps maintain quality
and decrease defects in your

infrastructure, this allows
you to speed up deployments

for systems you migrate from
the data center as well as new

systems that you build in the
cloud.

With this approach, your teams
can operate at a higher level

of abstraction and concentrate
on getting systems built,

rather than having to do repetitive
work.

The key to operating in the cloud
is continual improvement:

creating systems, such as infrastructure
as code, to operate environments,

and then concentrating
on improving those systems
over time.

Rather than trying to predict
the technology you’ll need and

then trying to buy or build
it, you can instantly access

ready-made IT services with
no upfront investment.

This allows you to focus on what
really matters to your organization:

growing your business and serving
your customers.

For more information
on this topic, check out the links
in the description.
Thanks for watching.
